In SWE2 the Workflows are linked and activated. 
 
In OAWF I linked an agent (US) to the tasks (TS03100055  or TS03100039). 
 
Additionally, I made the setting for Equipment Workflow --> Activate Asset Accounting (Link Object Type with Asset Class) and also I activated the workflow event for our equipment category in the PM Area. 
 
Nevertheless, what I am doing, I do not get the workflow working, only direct sync - even if direct sync is not chosen in customizing.
 
I guess we need to copy the sample workflows mentioned above from SAP, because here no E-Mail or approval steps are involved, correct? Also this I tried already, without any success. 
 
So long story short: I hope someone can help me in that matter, because I do not have any idea anymore what to do/change...

Nina

entry.title: Top Reasons to Modernize with SAP HANA Cloud – Blog #3 in the Series
entry.content:
Welcome back to my blog series on the value of migrating to SAP HANA Cloud. In the first two blogs, I discussed how features such as multi-model engines, infrastructure independence, and a next-generation application foundation all can help you build your business case for SAP HANA Cloud.

In fact, we’ve already seen powerful confirmation of the value of this database. For example, global consulting services provider CONTAX Inc. migrated to SAP HANA Cloud to gain the elasticity and scalability it needed to handle huge demands on its database resources. This modernization helped CONTAX expand its database capacity while reducing its overall memory footprint and cost by 25%.

That’s impressive. So how can you best estimate the benefits of migrating to SAP HANA Cloud for your enterprise?

Many organizations want to migrate their database to the cloud because they want to build and deploy intelligent applications at scale. But that requires an advanced data landscape architecture—a database-as-a-service (DBaaS) for modernizing your applications. Let’s talk about two capabilities of SAP HANA Cloud that help you meet that need and deliver exceptional value: intelligent data tiering and multi-dimensional elastic scalability.

Intelligent data tiering

The exploding growth of business data is both a cost issue and a management challenge for your business. How can you store the data users need and make it easily accessible without busting the budget?

Traditional database technology requires that you choose between database performance and costs. Should you pay more to over-provision storage space so data can be easily persisted in case of growing demands? Or should you archive data to save money but make data harder to access?

With SAP HANA Cloud, you can strike the right balance for your business.

 Intelligent, multi-temperature data management features help you store data in tiers according to type, operational usefulness, access frequency, and scalability requirements. The database locates frequently accessed, business-critical “hot” data in high-performance, in-memory storage, which facilitates real-time processing. “Warm” data requiring moderate access uses disk storage. Infrequently accessed “cold” data can be stored in a lower-cost data lake optimized for long-term retention and compliance.

By combining tiered storage with advanced virtualization capabilities, SAP HANA Cloud reduces cost and complexity while enabling optimum overall performance. Applications and users can query data at any tier without needing to know where the data is stored. Automatic optimization based on data location and access patterns eliminates complex, costly ETL processes—while supporting both operational efficiency and analytical depth. Data tiering also simplifies application development by offering one interface to multiple data tiers. Developers can use that interface to query data for applications without needing to know where the data is stored.

A recent IDC study [1] assessed database performance impacts for organizations that deployed SAP HANA Cloud. Query speed and response time improved by 31% and 29%, respectively. Backups executed 27% faster. Both data load time and recovery time were 24% faster.

“Data is more accessible with SAP HANA Cloud,” said one study participant. “It is also available in real time and loads far quicker than our previous environment. Our data performance has enhanced.”

Multi-dimensional elastic scalability

Another way SAP HANA Cloud helps you balance performance and cost is by enabling elastic scalability for data processing and storage across multiple dimensions. In today’s dynamic database environments, short-term processing peaks caused by issues such as period-end reporting surges, seasonal transactions, or heavy analytics workloads can create havoc.

Elastic scalability lets you adjust compute and storage resources based on workload demands, in real time. The database ramps up resources during periods of high demand and then reduces them during low-usage times to conserve costs. Flexible resources include:

  • Performance classes, with flexible CPUs and memory ratios
  • Elastic compute nodes, on-demand resources provisioned in minutes for data-intensive OLAP workloads
  • Dynamic scalability, with individual storage tiers that allow the database to grow or shrink as needed

SAP HANA Cloud also includes elasticity features such as class-based dynamic workload routing, which automatically sends queries to the most appropriate compute resources. An ECN advisor analyzes historical workload patterns and creates optimal provisioning schedules. To prevent scaling events from disrupting application performance, SAP HANA Cloud offers built-in monitoring and workload routing capabilities.

These elastic scalability features help you respond rapidly to changing business needs, enabling optimal performance without over provisioning resources. These features make data more accessible to users while reducing infrastructure complexity. Together, they can help you drive operational agility and cost-effective resource management.

With these benefits in mind, IDC evaluated the infrastructure costs of surveyed companies that deployed SAP HANA Cloud. Using its business value methodology, IDC concluded that the infrastructure costs of an SAP HANA Cloud environment were 20% less than a comparable database environment over a three-year period.

According to one study participant operating in the retail industry, “SAP HANA Cloud has given my organization the ability to scale and reduce redundancy, which are significant benefits.”

Explore other SAP HANA Cloud features to build your business case

Read the next blog to learn how native AI capabilities, built-in data integration, and automation that streamlines database administrator duties can help you build your business case for SAP HANA Cloud while preparing for the future of modern, intelligent applications and processes.

Additional resources:

What’s the potential value of SAP HANA Cloud for your organization? Complete a short assessment. 

Learn more about SAP HANA Cloud.

Discover how moving to SAP HANA Cloud helps you create a foundation for modernization.

Explore this guide on building a compelling business case to move your database to the cloud.

 

 [1] “The Business Value of SAP HANA Cloud,” IDC, sponsored by SAP, April 2025.

entry.title: Re: Give a Kudo, Get a Badge
entry.content:
Really enjoying this platform and diving deeper to gain insights, broaden my awareness, and expand my expertise. Currently, I am with McKesson, bringing over 20 years of experience in Accounting, Finance, and Finance Systems across diverse industries—including entertainment, education, telecommunications, and healthcare.

Recently, I have been deeply involved in FP&A transformation initiatives, which has been both challenging and rewarding. I spent years managing an IBM TM1 application and have now transitioned our business user base to SAP BPC and SAC. It’s been a fascinating journey—full of learning curves and a completely different look and feel.

Adapting to this change has been intense (I joke that I have aged a decade in past 3 years 😄), but it’s also been a valuable growth experience. I am hoping to connect with others navigating similar paths, especially those involved in S/4HANA transformation.

Let’s share, learn, and grow together!
